messages.content: Hi (:star) I’m <PERSON>. You can share anything here without judgment. What’s been weighing on your mind lately?
I feel lost about my career. My parents keep saying I should become a doctor like my cousin <PERSON>, but I hate medicine (:sad).
That’s tough. Feeling pulled in a direction that doesn’t fit your passions can create a lot of stress. What makes medicine feel wrong for you?
I don’t like the long hours, and I’m not interested in biology that much. I want to do something creative, maybe design or tech.
It’s great that you know what excites you. Creativity and tech are valid and valuable paths. Pressure from family can be heavy—have you tried talking to them about your interests?
I tried. My dad said on <DATE>: "You'll regret not choosing a stable career like medicine." (:angry)
That can feel discouraging. Stability is important, but so is fulfillment. Sometimes it helps to show your parents a plan that combines passion and practicality. What would your ideal path look like?
Maybe working in UI/UX design. I even started a portfolio website last month at <URL> but my mom laughed when she saw it.
Starting a portfolio shows initiative—that's impressive! Parental skepticism can sting, but your actions prove you're serious. What kind of feedback from them would help, if any?
Honestly, even just a "We see you're trying" would make me feel supported.
That's completely fair. Recognition matters. Small affirmations can make a big difference, especially when pursuing unconventional paths.
I also have anxiety about failing. Last week I sent an email to a design mentor asking for advice, and I’m still waiting for a reply. (:sad)
Waiting can be stressful, but reaching out shows courage. Mentors often have busy schedules, and a delayed reply doesn’t reflect your value or effort.
Yeah, I also fear my cousin <PERSON> will brag about med school again at family dinner on <DATE> (:sweat_smile).
Comparisons can hurt, especially with relatives. Remember, your path is unique. Maybe you can prepare a calm response, like "I'm exploring tech and design; I love learning in that field."
Good idea. I also practice coding and design at home using my old laptop but it crashes sometimes (:sad).
Even with technical hiccups, your persistence is impressive. Small setbacks don’t erase your progress—they’re just part of the journey.
Thanks. I also tried watching tutorials and it helped a bit.
That’s great! Structured learning can boost confidence. Would it help to set small weekly goals for your portfolio or coding practice?
Yes, I can aim to finish one design project each week.
Perfect. That makes your path tangible and reduces anxiety. You're taking control instead of feeling trapped by expectations.
Sometimes I even imagine telling my parents about a successful project I did. Last time, they barely looked at my certificate from the online course on <DATE>.

That can feel discouraging, but your achievements matter, not their reaction. Celebrating them for yourself is valid. Maybe share them selectively with people who support you, like your mentor <PERSON>.
Yes, I'll do that. Also, my friend <PERSON> said I should apply for a design competition in <LOCATION> next month.
That's an exciting opportunity! Competitions can validate your skills and give you exposure. How do you feel about applying?
Nervous but excited (:nervous). I think it could help prove to myself that I can do this.
Exactly. External validation is nice, but the most important validation is your own confidence. Each step you take reinforces it.
Thanks <PERSON>. Talking here makes me feel calmer.
I'm glad (:happy). You're already doing a lot—planning, practicing, reaching out for guidance. That's resilience in action. Keep trusting your instincts and passions.
